title: Cover for Steam and Sensibility by Kirsten Weiss
content:
I suspect that this steampunk fantasy title is graphical rather than font-based, but - just in case - might it be a font?

Font: 

 Kingthings Pique'n'meex 

Solved By: 

 [Mike F](http://web.archive.org/web/20140826124442/http:/typophile.com/user/3368 "View user profile.")

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [Screen Shot 2014-05-06 at 11.23.46.png](http://web.archive.org/web/20140826124442/http:/typophile.com/files/Screen%20Shot%202014-05-06%20at%2011.23.46_0.png) | 509.24 KB |
author: jamesmillner

comments.content: I immediately thought [Kevin King](http://web.archive.org/web/20140826124442/http:/www.kingthingsfonts.co.uk/fonts/fonts.htm). A look at some of his fonts will explain why. The font used was his Kingthings Pique'n'meex - about 4/5 of the way down the page.

Font or not, the letter-forms hiding under it remind me of Caslon 224 Bold [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/itc/caslon-no-224/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140826124442/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/itc/caslon-no-224/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/itc/caslon-no-224/")  
Don
Thanks Mike! And I love that webpage - full of entertainment...

You are certainly welcome, James.

Don - While I appreciate your point - a poor choice by Mr. King to use an existing Caslon. - I can't imagine that any foundry, including ITC, would raise a hint of protest at this use of their font for this type of end result. The competitive sales value is zero.

Waitng for Hrant to appear ...
